comment: neutralized between consequentialist, deontological, and aretaic conceptions of morality, and also between realist and anti-realist conceptions

diff.*:
Line 1: Line 1:  
{{Redirect|Appropriate||Appropriation (disambiguation)}}
 
{{Redirect|Appropriate||Appropriation (disambiguation)}}
−
'''Morality''' (from the [[Latin]] ''{{Lang|la|moralitas}}'' "manner, character, proper behavior") is the [[understanding]] that differentiates among intentions, decisions, and [[Social actions|actions]] between those that are good (or right) and bad (or wrong). A ''moral code'' is a system of morality (for example, according to a particular [[philosophy]], [[religion]], [[culture]], etc.) and a ''moral'' is any one practice or teaching within a moral code. The [[adjective]] ''moral'' is synonymous with "good" or "right." ''Immorality'' is the active opposition to what one believes to be moral (i.e. good or right), while ''amorality'' is variously defined as an unawareness of, indifference toward, or disbelief in any set of moral standards or principles.
+
'''Morality''' (from the [[Latin]] ''{{Lang|la|moralitas}}'' "manner, character, proper behavior") is the differentiation among intentions, decisions, and [[Social actions|actions]] between those that are good (or right) and bad (or wrong). A ''moral code'' is a system of morality (for example, according to a particular [[philosophy]], [[religion]], [[culture]], etc.) and a ''moral'' is any one practice or teaching within a moral code. The [[adjective]] ''moral'' is synonymous with "good" or "right." ''Immorality'' is the active opposition to morality (i.e. good or right), while ''amorality'' is variously defined as an unawareness of, indifference toward, or disbelief in any set of moral standards or principles.
